Thanks for your suggestions, Ken and Julian. I bumped it up to a gig
with -Xmx1000m and it works now.

Normal single pole-balancing works now with JNeat, and I'll post a
version to the files section of the group when I comment my code.

Ciao Ugo,

Sorry it's taken me a while to get back to you. I put the error aside
for a while because I was in the middle of final exams, but I just
started working with JNeat again. Increasing the java heap size seems to
have fixed the problem.

Anyway, I modified gui.Generation.evaluate to make a
gui.Generation.genericEvaluate. It might be useful to make something
like this a permanent part of JNeat so that it isn't restricted to
test-target data sets but can also be used for continuous feed-back
problems such as pole-balancing.

Have you thought about putting JNeat up on SourceForge? I'd like to work
on it a bit. The GUI is nice, although there are some ways it can be
simplified. Eventually it might be good to merge JNeat's GUI and logging
stuff and ANJI's codebase. I've also thought about trying to use JmDNS
(i.e. zero-conf or Rendezvous) and RPC/CORBA so that multiple machines
running JNeat will be able to work on the same problem, speeding up
evolution a lot.

I'll send you the work I've done so far with pole-balancing in another
email. There is only single pole balancing (not double). Right now it is
set up to do evolution using an image of the pole and cart. To make it
into a normal pole balancing evolution that uses 5 inputs, change 
"pole = new PoleBalancing(gridInputs);"
to
"pole = new PoleBalancing();"
in roober.pole_fit.java

and change 
"public static final int nInputs = BinaryInputs.W * BinaryInputs.H;"
to
"public static final int nInputs = 5;"
in pole_inp.java

Ciao,
Reuben


On Dec 14, 2004, at 3:00 AM, Ugo wrote:



Hello Reuben

(I truly ask forgiveness for my bad English and the delay but I have
approached to single Internet point in determines periods , not every
day !) 

I have read your question but for being able to help I would have need
of knowing something more to you: 

1) the error message happens before during running or that beginnings
the generation? it tries to see where you have error putting of the
signallings or write in the program between the several ones is made
that beginnings before evolution

2) you have used one class for input/ouput-target or a dataset fixed?
if you have used the class it controls that the vector d[. ] it is
with correct size for computeFitness and main-application.

3) if tests to visualize the genome that you have constructed come
visualized in correct way?



Not is a lot but if in worse of cases if you want test to send me the
genome that uses and the modifications to make in order to try in my
PC to simulate the error

  Hello 
              Ugo


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Reuben Grinberg <reuben.grinberg@y...>
wrote:
Hey Guys,

I'm using jNeat and I just modified the code so I could do 
pole-balacing. It works fine, and now I'm trying to use image
input. 
Right now the input is small-ish - 30 x 50 = 1500. I generated one 
random genome, and am using that as the starting genome file. Now
I'm 
getting OutOfMemory errors. Any suggestions?

Thanks,
Reuben
